name: Into a world of colour
description: Filmmakers have been using colour as a method of storytelling since the first moving pictures. Colour can be used to signify emotion, intensify drama or to create a strong visual aesthetic.

key_work.title: Into a World of Colour
key_work.brief_description: Since the beginning of cinema, filmmakers experimented with colour and sound by hand-tinting frames and providing orchestral accompaniments. But it wasn’t until the early 20th century that ‘talkies’ truly changed the industry and glorious Technicolor ushered in the first golden age of cinema.

links.description: Alfred Hitchcock uses the evocative symbolism of saturated colours in Vertigo to give greater insight into the narrative. Red and green are heavily contrasted between the main characters: red represents caution and danger for Scottie while green embodies illusion and desire for Madeline.

end.brief_description: The wife of an abusive criminal finds solace in the arms of a kind regular guest in her husband’s restaurant.

links.description: Peter Greenaway also uses highly saturated colours to highlight character development and to represent different locations. Blue for outside, green for the kitchen, red for the dining area and white for the bathroom, while Georgina’s clothing changes to symbolise her character’s growth.

end.title: In the Mood for Love
end.creator_credit: Wong Kar-wai, William Chang, Block 2 Pictures, Jet Tone Production, Orly Films, Paradis Films and Universal Pictures
end.brief_description: In 1962 Hong Kong, Chow (Tony Leung) and Li-zhen (Maggie Cheung) are neighbours. Their respective spouses are having an affair and the two lonely souls find themselves increasingly attracted to each other, but resist repeating the betrayals of their partners.

constellations_primary.name: Wong Kar-Wai's Hollywood fingerprints
constellations_primary.description: Wong Kar-wai’s modern masterpiece In The Mood For Love is a rich, romantic melodrama that follows the entangled lives of two neighbours (Tony Leung and Maggie Cheung) who develop feelings for each other after learning their spouses are having an affair.

constellations_other.name: Into a world of colour

links.description: Wong Kar-Wai’s In the Mood for Love is a sumptuous romantic melodrama that relies on a deep colour palette to depict raw emotions and is often bathed in rich reds and oranges. The colour system is then broken when the romance disintegrates.

end.title: Do the Right Thing
end.creator_credit: Spike Lee, Ruth E. Carter, 40 Acres and a Mule Filmworks, Universal Pictures and Wynn Thomas
end.brief_description: Do the Right Thing is a 1989 American comedy-drama film produced, written, and directed by Spike Lee. The story explores a Brooklyn neighbourhood’s simmering racial tension, which culminates in violence and a death on a hot summer day.

constellations_other.name: Into a world of colour
constellations_other.description: Filmmakers have been using colour as a method of storytelling since the first moving pictures. Colour can be used to signify emotion, intensify drama or to create a strong visual aesthetic.

links.description: Spike Lee uses a similar colour palette in Do the Right Thing, yet here such colours are employed to intensify the heat wave central to the story, with even buildings being tainted red and orange to illustrate the stifling New York summer.

links.description: To replicate the bold graphic novel the series is based on, director Marc Munden and colourist Aidan Farrell used the Technicolor palette of 1950s Hollywood for TV thriller Utopia, dressing the set in rich hues before emboldening them in post-production to create the sci-fi world.

end.title: Marie Antoinette
end.creator_credit: Callum Greene, Ross Katz, Sofia Coppola and Pricel
end.headline_credit: France, Japan and United States of America, 2006
end.brief_description: The retelling of France’s iconic but ill-fated queen, Marie Antoinette. From her betrothal and marriage to Louis XVI at 15 to her reign as queen at 19 and ultimately the fall of Versailles.

links.description: In contrast, Sofia Coppola colours her films with subdued pastels, most evident in Marie Antoinette. With the Palace of Versailles as the backdrop, Coppola incorporated a luscious yet dreamy palette highlighting the opulence of the young Queen’s life.

end.title: Tilly Dunnage's (Kate Winslet) red silk dress from The Dressmaker
end.credit_line: Courtesy The National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
